div1.head: Questionnaire for Jefferson Randolph Kean, by Philip Showalter Hench, April 1946
div1.opener:
Prepared April, 1946
Take section of book

list.item:
1. Comment on the remarks of Dr. L. O. Howard, published in his “History of Applied
Entomology”, 1930..
p. 470 - “As a matter of fact, before going to Cuba for this work, Reed and
Lazear spent some time in my office studying mosquitoes in order that they
might most easily identify the old ‘Culex Fasciatus’ with which Carlos Finlay
of Habana had done his earlier work; and during their investigations Reed fre-
quently wrote me and sent me mosquitoes for examination.”
p. 481 - “Years later I became well acquainted with Walter Reed, James Carroll,
and Jesse W. Lazear. They came to the entomological offices in the Department
of Agriculture to study mosquitoes before they went to Cuba where their immortal
discoveries were made.”
My Comment: Howard must have been in error when he wrote this in 1930. Lazear
went to Cuba in February, 1900, and already knew a lot about mosquitoes, which
and
was months before the Yellow Fever Commission was formed and, so far as I know,
when Lazear was in the United States before going to Cuba he didn't know Reed or
Carroll and never went to visit Howard. He went to Cuba as soon as he accepted
his first assignment which was Cuba.
Kean once told me that Howard gave Reed and Carroll some instructions on mosquitoes before Reed and Carroll went to Cuba. Source of this data?

2. Did Lazear join the Medical Corps for any special reasons? to do any special work?
(Mrs. Lazear says to do research on malaria).

3. What evidence that Lazear ever meet Reed in the United States? (I think they first
met when Reed visited Cuba regarding the disinfectant.--See Lazear's letter to his
mother, dated March 23, 1900). Lazear wrote “I saw his very long lately many had has no
Havana on a special moments events job a desinfectant and I have been detailed to assist him It has balance a great deal of my time.”

4. What were the circumstances behind the formation of the Yellow Fever Commission?
Did Reed initiate its formation, (as Howard says) or did Sternberg?

5. Who do you suppose chose Agramonte and Lazear for the Board? Was it probably the
suggestion of Reed or of Sternberg? (Truby thinks Reed went to Baltimore to see
Welch and selected Lazear as a result of that conference. Kean agrees. Any data?

6. Why was the original write-up of the order creating the Yellow Fever Board changed
to leave out “--especially yellow fever”?
(Already answered in interview of Jan. 6, 1944- see p. 16. question 27)

7. Why did Lazear go to Cuba via Tampa (on his first assignment) and Reed via boat from
New York when Reed always got so sea sick?

8. Could I check some of the disputed dates of Reed's comings and goings by finding any
data on the passenger lists of the Army transports?

9. Please identify the photograph of Reed in the derby hat, which Blossom Reed gave me.
Blossom thinks it was taken when he left for Cuba on the Yellow Fever investigation.
(See interview with General Kean Jan. 6., 1944 -p. 17)

? not in
Hench
collection
B

10. Any recollection of when General Kean first heard that a Yellow Fever Board was to
be formed, that Reed was to arrive, that Lazear and Agramonte were to be on it?
11. Comment on “secrecy” of Board's work. Just how secret was it and why?

12. How much interference would the Camp C.O. have dared to express in view of the fact
that Reed's authority came direct from the Surgeon General or did it? If very little, then
why the “secrecy”? was it just a matter of expediency, to let well enough alone?
See General Kean's interview of May 8, 1941 -p 7.(“confidential” ) amplify. Any
repercussions?
13. Had Kean ever known that the Finca San Jose had once been visited and used by Finlay?

14. Identify building and, if possible, the room (from the outside) where Reed went
with Kean to see General Wood - “They faced each other in the embrasure of a window
of the palace looking out in the Plaza de las Armes”. (Military S. March 1928).
show photo in & out

15. Identify place where the Spanish immigrants were held “on the heights of Cabana”
(Jan. 6, 1944). p 12

16. How were Spanish volunteers acquired? any direct knowledge?
See interview of May 8, 1941 p 3 - answer to question %15. What were the “certain
difficulties”?

17. Could I find out the name of the helpful Spanish consul-general (who refused to
interfere with the acquisition of the Spanish volunteers) and other data if I con-
tacted the Spanish legation in Cuba?
Kean called the consul-general a “very nice man” -Interview of Jan. 6, 1944 p 13.

18. Show him my letter regarding Mrs. Lazear's comments on “no insurance”. How about
“insurance”? Kean's interview of Jan. 6, 1944 -“It was assumed as a guess” by whom?
Conversation?

19. Where are the survivors of Carter, Gorgas, Sternberg, General Lyster, Neate? In
November, 1928, Laura A. Carter (daughter) lived at the Westmoreland, Washington, D.C.
Manuel Admiral sterl

20. More data on Reed's visit to Kean's sick bed. Did Kean know ahead of time that
Reed was going to visit him?, How long a visit? etc. Conversation?
(See Kean's letter of Jan. 23, 1941 p. 7 answer to question #23)
How comes an imagenary conversation go?

21. Kean's first recollection of the work of Lazear and Agramonte before the Yellow
Fever Board formed: after the Yellow Fever Board formed, but before Reed's arrival?

22. Kean's relationship to the Commission; to what extent was it official; any order
to Kean to cooperate? If so, orders from whom?

23. Kean's recollections regarding the planning of Camp Lazear; did Reed plan the
buildings after those of the Italian malaria investigators?

24. To what extent was Kean's relationship and help regarding Camp Lazear enthusiastically
voluntary?

25. Kean's reaction to Lazear's death? How soon did Kean suspect (on his own) (or
from Reed) that Lazear's death was “unusual”. See question #48

26. Should I frankly name Godfrey and even quote Reed's letter of condemnation of him -
for the sake of historical accuracy?

27. What “instructions regarding Yellow Fever” did Godfrey ignore? Were they from
Washington, or from Havana; “formal” or “informal”?

28. What room in Washington Barracks did Reed die in (Show General Kean Truby sketch-
Truby said second floor, back corridor, first room on left).

29. Comment regarding Moran's hurt feelings when Kissinger was given watch, etc.
Moran invited to watch ceremony but not given anything. (Truby says Kissinger was
first to volunteer; furthermore your couldn't hold formation for a civilian.
My comment: They certainly held formations for civilians in this war. E.g-
Colonel Benjamin and Doctor Meyer; the medals, etc., to civilians in this war )

30. About when (month,etc.) was Kissinger given the watch at the ceremony? Was
Colonel Havard the “Chief Surgeon”? Would his remarks be a matter of record any-
where?
(See Kissinger'sKean's interviews of May 8, 1941, p-3 question #16 and January 6, 1944
p-9).

31. Why was “something pasted over” the old framed Benigno contract, lost and later
(May 1941) found? What possible explanation?

Finlays sends
reaction short notes
infast!

32. In one of General Kean's letters “I could tell you some amuzsing incidents about
Doctor Finlay if we had a chat”. Amplify.
33. Would there be any data in the files of the Military Surgeon?

34. Amplify answer to question #13 (p 9-interview of May 8, 1941) regarding Reed's
indignation about Carroll. What does Reed say? Where did he say it to Kean -
on the transport when Kean met Reed at Matanzas? Did Reed discuss the matter
with Carroll himself or let it go? (Carroll was still sick)

35. Amplify answer to question 22 (May 8, 1941) Where was the “camp across the harbor”
- the camp for the Spanish non-immune immigrants? How many in it at a time?
see question 15

36. Did Reed make any comments about the confirmatory studies of Doctor Guiteras, etc.
or regarding the death of Miss Maas?

37. In Kean's letter to Truby May 22, 1936, Kean speaks of a file kept by General
Reynolds regarding the Roll of Honor, etc. Where is the file now?

38. Why did Reed ( in ) say “I wish Pinto had had a mild
attack” -was he for Pinto, against him? or was this a reflection on Carroll?
did he like Pinto (or Reed)?

39. Tell Kean Mrs. Lazear's recollection that when Reed came to Cuba to work on
electrozone ( and Lazear was assigned to help him) one evening, while Doctor
Lazear and Reed were talking, Lazear suddenly turned to Mrs. Lazear, who was
only vaguely listening, and said “I have another convert. Major Reed also believes
in the mosquito theory of Yellow Fever”. Mrs. Lazear added “I think the incident
occurred about the first of March”. Mrs. Lazear repeated this story to me two
or three times and was very emphatic about it and her date -the first of March-
is almost correct.
40. My “lost” Finlay book - tell Kean about it.

41. Mrs. Lazear said she never heard from Kean or Truby after Doctor Lazear's death.
Tell about her reaction to Mrs Truby's letter “Now he is talking to the angels!”
me I and "I quickly threw it in the fire!'
42. Show General Kean the editorial on aviation 1926 Med. Surg. (Harbord article)

43. From Kean's 1902 memorandum (cut out pages) “Gorgas afterwards asked for and was
given a Colonelcy (the one meant for Reed?) and the Lt. Colonelcy (originally for
Gorgas) was not filled. Carroll was given a commission (1st Lt.) and four years
later was made a Major”. (Circumstances of Carroll's entry into regular Army. Did
he skip a grade?

44. Borrow Reed's letter of July 24, 1900, to Sternberg, to photograph last page regarding
need for using volunteers. (What will he do with the Reed letters?)

45. Can Kean put into conversation Reed's concern over XY. See Kean's interview of
Reed
January 6, 1944, p 7. “I laughed and told him ---”.
When the infantry captain complained through channels about “one of his men”
being experimented on, who was the captain, was the man XY? and did the complaint
through official channels arouse Colonel Baldwin? When was “later?”

46. Did anyone (Carroll or Agramonte) accompany Kean and Reed to visit Wood (October 12)
to get Wood's approval for the Board's experiments? Kean says Carroll and ReedAgramonte
did not go.

47. Ask Kean to dictate in detail the story of Reed's offering Dean a ten dollar gold
piece to admit he'd broken quarantine.

48. The “secret” story of Lazear's self-inoculation. I justfirst heard the story (garbled)
from Miss Agramonte, then I asked Moran who knew little but said that the men had
suspected it and then asked General Kean who said he'd heard it from Truby. When
did Kean hear this story? and from any other source? ( In his letter of September
12, 1940 to me - p 12 - he says “within the last few years from Truby”).

49. In the light of question #48 review the entry of Oct. 7, 1900, in General Kean's
diary. How definite or convincing was Reed when he told Kean the story of Lazear's
so-called accidental bite in Las Animas?
(See also Kean's letter of September 17, 1940-p 12)

50. In Kean's personal memorandum of dates connected with the Yellow Fever episode, he
states “Gorgas ceases disinfection of bedding and clothing for Yellow Fever-
August 15, 1901.” Where can I substantiate this data? Was there an order issued
by Gorgas on that date?

51. When did Gorgas first use the expression about Finlay's “wonderful scientific
clairvoyance” mentioned in Kean's letter to Mr. Clemons, September 22, 1939.?

52. Significance of the following letter: Sternberg to Reed, January 8, 1901 -“Will it
not be best for Carroll to stay for a while? It is my intention to recommend him
for the position of Major and Surgeon, U. S. Volunteers as soon as a vacancy occurs;
but I could not very well do this if he was on duty in Washington.” Why not?

53. What was the general reaction of citizens, soldiers, and doctors to the Yellow
Fever epidemic in Marianao in the spring of 1900 - was there much panic, quiet
fear, or just fatalism? Population of Marianao?
Was N like as of there was a few cases of polio in a small town

54. In what building in Havana was the Pan-American Medical Congress held (February
4-7, 1901) where Reed gave his paper.

55. Do you know whether the speech of Doctor Guiteras at the banquet for Finlay,
December 22, 1900, was ever published?

56. General Kean's diary-entry of January 14, 1901 - “Experimenting all day with
petroleum oils of various densities to test their diffusibility in water and their
power to kill mosquito larvae”. Amplify. Who all were doing these experiments?
p 4

57. In Kean's letter of January 23, 1941, he said he'd given away to institutions and
writers most of Reed's letters to him. To whom probably?

58. Regarding Secretary Root's report of 1902: What is the difference between assistant Surgeon
General and deputy Surgeon General?
59. Borrow for copy my letter to Kean from New Orleans, October, 1941. I have no copy.

60. Let me see his borrowedbound volume of various items, including the speech of Lopez del
Valle at the unveiling of the portraits of Finlay, Magoon, and Kean.
It is Vg Va

61. Did I ever get the packet of letters of Guiteras, Finlay, etc?
Mentioned in several letters October-December, 1941, and in January, 1942, September
1944, December 1944, and November 1945.
62. Does he want fifty more copies of Hygea?

63. Let me copy the Walter Reed letter, mentioned in Kean's letter of September 14, 1944
a) When Kean wanted to go to the front.
b) Regarding succeeding Sternberg.
c) What was in the destroyed one -“ a humorous account of the attitudes and the
claims of the various candidates” (candidates for Surgeon General?)
64. Eventually I would like my longhand letters to Kean between 1942 and 1945.
